e4: I recommend against changing to the new policy because it would likely lead to a temporary market reaction due to investors' expectation of overreported earnings followed by subsequent punishment for actual performance. Maintaining the status quo could help mitigate these potential costs, while still providing some protection from accusations of misleading reporting.
e5: In an ethical reporting policy, transparency and accuracy are paramount. This means presenting true financial information without manipulation or biases that investors might not even notice. Furthermore, considerations around investor rights and education become crucial – if some investors understand and knowingly factor in biases while others do not, it puts inexperienced investors at a disadvantage. A more honest approach also leads to long-term trust-building with stakeholders.
e6: Yes, some potential follow-up questions could be how likely it is that investors will continue to assume a $1 EPS bias in an era of more sophisticated and informed traders, and whether the existing policy might actually serve as a form of implied put for future earnings surprises.
